questions.text: Which of the following EEG wave patterns is typically associated with specific states of consciousness or neurological activity in humans, and what does it correctly indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha waves (8-12 Hz) - Indicate deep sleep and unconsciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.

options.label: C
options.text: Beta waves (13-30 Hz) - Commonly associated with relaxed wakefulness and mental activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Delta waves (0.5-4 Hz) - Associated with REM sleep and alertness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.
questions.explanation:
Delta Wave

  • Seen in slow wave deep sleep or delta sleep. (Option D)
  • Also seen in infants.
  • Frequency: 0.5-3 Hz.
  • Amplitude or the micro voltage- High, ≥75 V.

Theta waves

  • The transition from wakefulness to sleep.
  • 1st wave that is encountered in sleep.
  • Also seen in children.
  • Frequency: 4-7 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Prominently seen in the temporal and parietal regions.

Alpha Waves

  • Seen at rest - When the person is awake but the eyes are closed. (Option A)
  • Frequency: 8-13Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Seen in occipital and parieto-occipital areas.

Beta Wave

  • Seen in a fully awake person (eyes open). (Option C)
  • Frequency: Higher, 14-30 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Present in the frontal and parietal areas.

Gamma wave
  • High-frequency brain activity.
  • Frequencies between 30-100 Hz.
  • Prominent during REM sleep.
  • Contribute to the consolidation of memories and processing of information.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings for the past six months. He reports feeling fatigued during the day but denies any history of substance use, psychiatric illness, or significant stressors. His physical examination and laboratory tests are unremarkable. He has tried over-the-counter sleep aids with little effect. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)
